B000E5N6LG|5.0|Lawrence Kasdan's &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; got a raw deal in 1994 when it was released; the movie &#34;Tombstone&#34; -- essentially the same story -- came out six months earlier and stole its thunder. The difference in these two films can be observed in their names: &#34;Tombstone&#34; focuses on Earp's conflict with the 'Cowboys' gang in the Arizona town, whereas &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; is an epic Western detailing Earp's life from youth to old age, although the Tombstone events are certainly the center piece. &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; runs 3 hours 11 minutes and &#34;Tombstone&#34; is an hour shorter. Both are top-of-the-line modern Westerns and whether you'll like one or the other depends on what you're in the mood for. If you want kinetic mythmaking &#34;Tombstone fills the bill, but if you want realistic storytelling with the details and mundaneness thereof then &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; is the way to go. Regardless, both are vastly superior to the dull 1957 version with Burt Lancaster and Kirk Douglas, &#34;Gunfight at the O.K. Corral.&#34;<br /><br />I originally saw &#34;Tombstone&#34; sometime in the 90s, but by the time I got around to seeing &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; I had forgotten the former film; as such, &#34;Tombstone&#34; wasn't able to 'steal the thunder' from my viewing of Costner's version. I was engrossed throughout. It may not be as great as his &#34;Dances with Wolves&#34; (1990), but it's not far off and, besides, few Westerns stand equal with that one.<br /><br />I recently saw both films back-to-back and it is fun comparing the two. Val Kilmer from &#34;Tombstone&#34; wins out over Dennis Quaid as Doc Holiday, but not by much and not because Quaid is bad but rather because Holiday's role is more prominent in &#34;Tombstone&#34; with better lines. Actually Kilmer is nothing less than fascinating in the role, although Quaid is more believable. Kurt Russell and Costner are about even as Earp, but &#34;Tombstone&#34; wins out overall in cast with Sam Elliott, Powers Boothe, Michael Biehn, Billy Zane and the shining Dana Delany as Josie, although Joanna Going in the same role in &#34;Wyatt&#34; shines just as much. But there are several exceptions; for instance, Isabella Rossellini in &#34;Wyatt&#34; edges out Joanna Pacula as Big Nose Kate, Doc's babe.<br /><br />As for the dramatic walk to the O.K. Corral and the gunfight itself I favor &#34;Wyatt Earp,&#34; but &#34;Tombstone&#34; has a better dramatic build-up to the confrontation. However, &#34;Tombstone&#34; loses too much steam after the gunfight with redundant shootouts between Wyatt & his men and the Cowboys; &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; maintains better momentum in the final act where the train sequence is much more impressive than the quick rendition shown in &#34;Tombstone.&#34;<br /><br />Unlike &#34;Tombstone,&#34; which was shot in Arizona, &#34;Wyatt&#34; was shot in New Mexico, with additional scenes shot in South Dakota, Port Angeles, WA, and Burbank Studios, CA.<br /><br />FINAL WORD: Don't listen to the moron critics who undeservedly bashed &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; upon release in '94. They're wrong, pure and simple. &#34;Tombstone&#34; was evidently too fresh in their minds and ruined the story for them. &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; easily stands with the all-time best Westerns. Just make sure you're in the mood for a 3-hour-plus epic before viewing. And, by all means, catch &#34;Tombstone&#34; too -- they're both great.<br /><br />GRADE: A-iehn, Billy Zane and the shining Dana Delany as Josie, although Joanna Going in the same role in &#34;Wyatt&#34; shines just as much. But there are several exceptions; for instance, Isabella Rossellini in &#34;Wyatt&#34; edges out Joanna Pacula as Big Nose Kate, Doc's babe.   As for the dramatic walk to the O.K. Corral and the gunfight itself I favor &#34;Wyatt Earp,&#34; but &#34;Tombstone&#34; has a better dramatic build-up to the confrontation. However, &#34;Tombstone&#34; loses too much steam after the gunfight with redundant shootouts between Wyatt & his men and the Cowboys; &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; maintains better momentum in the final act where the train sequence is much more impressive than the quick rendition shown in &#34;Tombstone.&#34;  Unlike &#34;Tombstone,&#34; which was shot in Arizona, &#34;Wyatt&#34; was shot in New Mexico, with additional scenes shot in South Dakota, Port Angeles, WA, and Burbank Studios, CA.  FINAL WORD: Don't listen to the moron critics who undeservedly bashed &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; upon release in '94. They're wrong, pure and simple. &#34;Tombstone&#34; was evidently too fresh in their minds and ruined the story for them. &#34;Wyatt Earp&#34; easily stands with the all-time best Westerns. 031606792X|2.0|As the Twilight series continued, what started out as a mediocre book blossomed into a subpar series.  While none of the books could ever be considered great literature, the quality steadily declined from the first to the last novel.  This one features more disturbing elements (Edward's controlling behavior, the imprinting of Jacob on a baby still covered in placenta practically) but never seems to bring about the emotional high that was the saving grace of the others.  While in Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse Meyers taps into the well of human reactions and psyche (however shallowly), Breaking Dawn doesn't quite make it.  The action rises and rises but the denoument is so unsatisfactory it leaves even the most hardcore fans salivating for some kind of legitimate conclusion.  Akin to George Lucas's sing-song happy ending of The Return of the Jedi (which at least had the appeal of being substantive in the rest of the series if we don't count the newest three films), all the vampires and werewolves resolve their differences and live happily ever after forever and ever and ever (since none of them seem to ever die) in a perfect paradise where they also never eat humans.  The big threat that will destroy them all is neutralized by one piece of information from Alice and the big showdown just sort of dissolves in one big anticlimactic heap.  Isn't that peachy.  The end is just one big cliche-fest, which might be alright if she hadn't already worn out every aphorism, cliche, and tired metaphor in literature in the first three books.  As it is, the ending is almost unbearably sticky-sweet.  There is no real loss or hardship to remind the characters of how phenomenally lucky they are or how truly beautiful life is.  There is no real risk or danger, even though there is a potentially serious threat to their existence, and so it almost feels as if they cheated.  The best resolution involves real struggle which takes from the characters and makes them question the meaning of life and their place in it.  When everything is basically handed to them, that appreciation of and meaning to their lives falls flat and stagnant.  The rest of the plot is uneventful.  Whenever there seems to be a bump in the road, Meyers carefully removes it before anything too dire happens.  Jacob finally gets it through his head that he can't have Bella -- so he imprints on her child instead, bringing in the vague concept of pedophilia.  Seen through a certain lens, this book almost encourages it by saying that it's okay for Jacob to be totally and completely in love with a baby who hasn't even mastered basic motor skills or language because it's meant to be.  No, that excuse will not get you out of jail when you molest a thirteen-year-old.  Bella is perennially clumsy and uncoordinated as a human -- forever a hindrance to her abilities -- but as a vampire she's the most naturally talented of them all, and has more self-discipline and control than any newborn they've ever seen!  Golly gee!  To top it all off, she gets everything she wants in one fell swoop: a baby, a new life as a vampire, and basically an entire makeover.  The message here: the most fulfilling life is one where you're a happily married gorgeous mother.  Like all the other books, it's a clear case of teenage wish fulfillment.  Everything she ever wants comes true and all the roadblocks get magically cleared away so she can live this dream for the rest of eternity.  Aside from the banal plot, the characters continue to be basically one-dimensional.  Bella manages to balance her attention (which is where all her personality is directed) between Edward and Renesmee (a name even worse than Albus Severus Potter).  She literally has no life without the two of them.  Additionally, all her time is spent either catering to the every whim of one of the two of them (what a brat that kid's going to be) or having wild jungle sex with Edward for eight to ten hours straight every night because vampires don't gettired.  Ultimately, this book and this series preys on the insecurities and desires of a wide variety of people, but mostly girls and mostly younger girls (although let's not exclude guys, here, either).  By creating a shell of a character anybody can easily fit themselves into, everyone can experience, however briefly, the same fulfillment of all their unrealistic hopes and dreams -- a perfect man, a perfect life forever, and unblighted happiness.  To an even greater extent than Disney ever imagined or Barbie ever hoped, the Twilight saga has latched onto the minds of young girls like the proverbial blood-sucking leech and will forever warp their ideas of love, relationships, and happiness.  At least therapists will have plenty of work in the next few decades when these kids grow up and realize that Edward is an unrealistic idealization and that happiness is intertwined with hardship and sorrow.tired. By creating a shell of a character anybody can easily fit themselves into, everyone can experience, however briefly, the same fulfillment of all their unrealistic hopes and dreams -- a perfect man, a perfect life forever, and unblighted happiness. I think trimming a half hour off of it would have helped.    Also, this is one of those early films that relied too heavily on obvious CGI monsters (obvious because the lighting on them does not quite match their environment) that briefly pop up at unexpected moments.  Basically there is just a jumble of CGI tentacles coming through pipes and walls and doors through most of the film.  Finally, at the end of this overlong film one gets to see THE monster which is some sort of giant man eating octopus...I think.  If they had just used a few actors in rubber octopus suits that attached and ate expendable cast members who had occasionally wondered off by themselves, then that would probably have been MORE effective!    Overall:    Yeah, I would still recommend this film to the sci-fi / horror film fan just for the excellent acting by the leads and the claustrophobic environment of the ship they are all stuck on.  The explosions look good, too.  But, be prepared, because I think you will find the giant sea monster a bit of a disappointment.

While only twenty-seven minutes in length, it is precisely what the movie Gimmie Shelter is not and for that, I am eminently grateful. If only we could have the entire show put out coupled with the priceless off stage footage of the band instead of lawyers and promoters, you'd have a documentary of the tour that would be the fitting tribute it started out to be. There are five full songs (Prodigal Son, You Gotta Move, Under My Thumb, I'm Free, and Satisfaction), some backstage celeb moments, and other little tidbits from both the pre-NYC shows as well as a few candid moments with Ian Stewart, Mick Jagger, and the Grateful Dead before Altamont. Lastly, there is a brief blues piano interlude from Keith that sounds exactly like those legendary Toronto tapes that were recorded many years later as he faced heroin charges and imprisonment. What price would you put on this rare footage?<br />There are three cds, one being the original release. The secondary cd of the unreleased tracks from the MSG show fairly completes what has long been missing and available on other boots of the tour and features a particularly endearing flub during Prodigal Son. A common whine is that they should've released the entire show, chronologically without editing. For those ocd among you, search out the numerous bootleg sites on line and buy it yourself or mix these songs together and form your own one disc set, but quit crying already. Is it just me or are Stones fans the biggest complainers in the world?  The third cd is the long overdue release of the opening acts. B.B. King is in fine form, easily as sharp and well-oiled as on Live at the Regal or at Cook County Jail. Although a short set, it's definitely something I'll be listening to often. Similarly, the brief Ike and Tina Turner portion is equally entertaining and the sizzling and sultry performance of I've Been Loving You Too Long loses nothing in the absence of her microphone stroking visual.<br />Lastly, the other items include a postcard replica of the tour poster, a freebie download of a song for Guitar Hero 5 (don't own), and a hardcover mini-book with photos, an essay, and some fan notes. Nothing major, but goodies nonetheless.<br />In summary, unlike so many packaged re-releases with supposed goodies and extras, the extra material herein is truly worthwhile and stands alone. There was not the option to simply get the bonus stuff without the additional copy of the original recording, so crying over what won't be is pointless. For me, this box is measured by the value herein and not so much by the price tag. Is it worth what it? That depends on how smart of a shopper you are.e sizzling and sultry performance of I've Been Loving You Too Long loses nothing in the absence of her microphone stroking visual. B00000DGUY|4.0|Dire Straits have released three Greatest Hits style compilations, and all of them contain some notable flaws. You'd think after three goes at it, they'd get it right, but apparently not so. 'Money For Nothing' contains some glaring omissions, while the 2CD 'Private Investigations' sounds more promising until you realise it also contains Knopfler's solo stuff. 'Sultans Of Swing' is probably the best of the bunch, since every album is represented to some degree, and it does contain most (if not all) of what fans want to hear.    As expected, the collection is dominated by 'Brothers In Arms' ('Walk Of Life', 'So Far Away', 'Your Latest Trick', 'Money For Nothing', and the title track) and 'On Every Street' ('Calling Elvis', 'Heavy Fuel', and the title track). That's fair enough I suppose, although it's a pity that a few more songs from the band's early days couldn't be included. There's certainly no arguing with 'Sultans of Swing', 'Lady Writer', 'Romeo And Juliet', 'Tunnel of Love', or 'Twisting By The Pool', but it would have been nice to include 'Down To The Waterline', and once again they leave out 'Industrial Disease'. There are a couple of other issues, in that several songs are presented in abbreviated radio edits instead of the album mixes, and the inclusion of Mark Knopfler's solo track from 'Local Hero' doesn't make much sense.     It's a pity that there's no one Dire Straits collection that provides a really comprehensive summary of their career, but we have to make the best of what we've got. Although it contains a couple of flaws, 'Sultans Of Swing' is the best bet for casual fans looking for the big hits, and newcomers to introduce themselves to the band.

I discovered the Nats by accident when I downloaded \\"All The Wine\\" from a free music site, knowing nothing about the band. I loved that song and the 1980s post-punk, WirePsycheldicFursNewOrderJoyDivision vibe that permeated the Alligator and Boxer. That vibe continues on High Violet to some extent although a few of the songs veer toward dense aimless noddling, than to music by the latest critics darling. I remember not being wowed by their musicianship when I saw them live a few years ago.    All of their releases have something to recommend them. I find High Violet to be a good listen, a little dense and murky at times. I don't attempt to analyze the poetry/lyrics of Matt B. but occasionally a lyrical couplet or a line stands out and sticks with me. If anything, his lyrics seem more concise here and less like amateur Poetry Night at the coffeehouse. High Violet is certainly performed with intensity, which is not always a good thing as this approaches arena rock levels throughout. Hopefully they will re-visit the low-key vibe that existed on their debut, the one with the dude in the swimming pool on the cover. I'd like to hear what they sound like now with the intensity reined in a little.    Yes, there is something about the Nats that I like. The less-stellar songs on High Violet aren't that bad and a few of them are outright moving. My favorite is \\"England\\". I love that song. It works for me the same way that lovely \\"Ada\\", from Boxer worked for me. The best National songs are mesmerizing, the average National songs don't send me running out ofthe room. The bad ones..well none of their songs are bad, actually.    Here is my unsolicited rank of the National releases.  1. Boxer  2. High Violet  3. Alligator  4. The one with the cover of the guy in the pool.  5. Sad Songs for Dirty Lovers.

B003JJA59K|1.0|While the actors in the film were very engaging, my first thought after watching the film was, \\"I want the two hours back I just wasted watching this\\".  I kept waiting for the story to get started. I generally like apocalyptic fiction, and do not require a happy ending, but this was just too bleak for my tastes.  The surviving populace seemed to be divided into three one dimensional categories - hopeless, helpless, and predatory.  While many stories in this genre tend to gloss over the decline of human beings into cannibalism by inserting a mind altering disease of some type (kudos for not using that cliche), this film expects us to accept that a significant portion of the population would devolve to cannibalism within a few years of (admittedly) drastic hunger. I just don't see it. While there are isolated cases of people preying on people as food in desperate conditions, the thought that it would be as widespread and as cold blooded as depicted in this film is hard to accept. I believe a more realistic portrait of humanity in these circumstances is packs of traveling protagonists assailed by loan wolf cannibals, rather than the reverse portrayed here. I guess I like my apocalyptic fiction to highlight the positives of humanity, rather than suggesting that those positives are freakish aberrations in a child.

B0030U1TLQ|5.0|Disintegration is a landmark achievement in popular music. Frequently heralded as one of the best records of the 1980's and of the new wave/alternative movement, this newly remastered and expanded edition features the original album in new remastered form, mixed louder and with more punch, but at the cost of some dynamic range. As expected from a modern remaster, the overall levels have been increased, but not in an offensive way and the record doesn't suffer from the heinous clipping that some remaster jobs get. Guitars sparkle anew, vocals echo and soar, bass slinks, and drums boom and pop on the twelve original tracks, all of which are classics in their own right. I'll forgo discussing the album in and of itself, because anyone considering buying this already knows that Disintegration is must-own. If all you're looking for is a more modern sound, then you've come to the right place, but never one to skimp, Robert has put together a very solid 3 disc set for the 20th anniversary of the album. The additional discs feature a fleshed out version of the 1990 Entreat live album, including a live take of each of the tracks from Disintegration, in the album's sequential order. These live cuts show the Cure in very solid, if not stellar, form, and is a definite treat for fans. The other disc is a collection of rarities, demos, and unreleased tracks recorded during the Disintegration sessions. Truly one for the fans, this collection of cuts will not likely appeal to casual fans, but for someone interested in hearing the evolution of these songs and of the album as a whole, the rarities collection is an interesting historical piece. I just wouldn't expect it to spend a whole lot of time in your car's CD player in lieu of the album proper. Another excellent addition to the Cure remaster series, I just wish it hadn't taken so long for the album to get arrive. Here's hoping the rest of the planned remasters are a little more expedient in their release.
0385512058|5.0|I consider this book a must-read. It is written cleanly, and organized around a number of relevant, diverse, and inspiring examples, that demonstrate a deep level of understanding and research on behalf of Ferrazzi. More importantly, the concepts in the book, and the light approaches to these concepts, are worth exploration and discussion, especially in our increasingly inter-connected world. Some reviewers have complained that this book is not specific enough in many respects, and they're right. This book is not a hard-nosed encyclopedia with all the information for navigating social events and closing business deals. And that's the beauty of the book. It's a light, efficient, and useful read for all because of this nature. Of course the story-line is a bit gimmicky, since Ferrazzi reminds us of his humble origins every 5 pages, but the treasures of this book are not lost as a direct result of it.    Each section of the book, I believe, provides an important, introductory overview of the power of human relations, harnessed for the mutual benefit of you and the person with whom you decide to forge a personal relationship. The specifics especially come in with regard to small talk and leading conferences. Both can be applied immediately in your personal business world. Ferrazzi also provides insight as to how to appear interesting, which to you skeptics out there, can also be applied to the current world of twitter and facebook. What differentiates you among the millions who are all broadcasting the banal, minutia of their everyday lives? This book gives you the starting blocks to being ahead of the pack. Yes, it doesn't have all the answers. But it gets you started, and in ways other books of its kind cannot. In short, I believe this book is a must-read and and an easy-read. I do not, however, endorse the sequel to this book, Who's Got Your Back. It is nothing like this book.

0465043577|4.0|(Note: first, I recommend that readers read Gaetan Lion's excellent review of this book.  My review addresses narrower, somewhat technical aspects of the book.  I apologize in advance for its great length.)<br /><br />Second, some backstory to this book.  Institutional investors such as insurance companies or brokerages usually do not focus on picking stocks per se; rather, they operate like an actuary, selecting the odds of particular outcomes and insuring against the bad outcomes in the cheapest way. For a large number of investors, the returns come from \\"cheaply-held risk,\\" meaning that risky (but potentially higher-performing) assets are insured against massive losses in the least expensive way prudent.  Naturally, a cheap way to hold risky assets is to not insure against risk, but of course this is extremely dangerous.<br /><br />For a smaller number of investors, the returns come from providing the insurance: writing put options, exotic swaps, and so on. Portfolio insurance (in the forms of exotic derivatives) has become a major source of income for the entire FIRE sector. Even if one nets out the immense losses of 2008, it's been a very lucrative business worldwide.  More about that in a minute.<br /><br />As with other forms of insurance, the paramount consideration is pricing risk, which depends on the size and frequency of market fluctuations.  In theory, these fluctuations not only ought to be random, but the frequency of each variation (ranked by size and direction) ought to map out a Normal (Gaussian) curve, as other random phenomena do.  Instead, it maps out other curves.  Since there MANY other curves that could potentially do the job--and softwares for applying them, too--this is not really a serious hurdle.  But the problem doesn't really end there.<br /><br />If anomalies like the 6 May 2010 1000-pt. drop in the Dow were randomly distributed THROUGH TIME, then adapting risk evaluation methods like the Black-Scholes formula (used to compute the value of derivatives) would be easy. Once we've replaced a Normal distribution with something that fits the data, we would still wrongly expect 6-May-2010 shocks to occur very far apart.  But while volatility overall is not at unprecedented levels, individual anomalies are larger and more frequent than ever; and even if we focus on much more commonplace events, we find that they have very un-even distribution through time. In fact, such shifts come in consecutive (or almost-consecutive) bursts; this is known as \\"autocorrelation,\\" and it makes a hash of any effort to actually price risk.<br /><br />Prudence says that capital managers should keep value at risk below 20% of the value of the portfolio, which should be easy with a reasonable amount of hedging.  But if one acknowledges the possibility both of very large numbers of anomalies, AND their autocorrelation (incidence close together in time), then hedging adequately becomes prohibitively expensive, eliminating gains from trading.<br /><br />Mandelbrot argues that the patterns of price changes are fractal in nature; the (log) price history for the Dow, for example, looks rather the same if you show a 330-day chart or a 330-minute chart.  Revealingly, he demonstrates how to use fractals to simulate a fictional trading chart that mimics the statistical behavior of the real stock.  However, after explaining this backstory (and including the marginally relevant story of H.E. Hurst's study of the Nile), the authors have little to add.  This is not the fault of fractals per se; indeed, several studies of multifractal models of asset returns (MMAR) compared to GARCH(1,1) suggest that fractals are indeed a stronger tool for capturing the true risk of asset returns.*<br /><br />Part of the problem may be the difficulty of explaining the mathematics/nature nexus clearly. Mandelbrot is not merely a brilliant mathematician, he's a gifted writer; his 1997 paper introducing MMAR is remarkably easy to read, considering its historical significance.  But for even broader diffusion, a prominent financial editor co-wrote the book, and probably decided the upper limit on how much could be explained to non-statisticians.<br /><br />However, a more serious issue is the lack of rationale for the revised theory. What I mean by this is, we can always tweak the mathematical model to produce results that approximate reality very closely.  As explained above, even a random (simulated) process is valuable to a trader, if the random process captures the statistical features of the real process--in this case, a time series of asset prices.  But if the mathematical model is nothing more than yet another shrink-to-fit snapshot of history, it's nothing more than data mining writ large.  It's as if I generated a Fourier series that precisely matched the movement of the Dow over many years; without an underlying narrative, it's nothing but an ingenious way to draw another chart of PAST price movements. The pattern and timing of anomalies could continue to change over time in a wholly unpredictable way, in the absence of an overriding explanatory narrative.<br />_______________________________________<br />* GARCH(1,1): generalized autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity. The (1, 1) refers to the number of lags of the conditional variance and the number of lags of the squared innovations.  An example of such a study would be Thomas Lux, \\"Multi-Fractal Processes as Models for Financial Returns\\" (1999).ial editor co-wrote the book, and probably decided the upper limit on how much could be explained to non-statisticians.  However, a more serious issue is the lack of rationale for the revised theory. What I mean by this is, we can always tweak the mathematical model to produce results that approximate reality very closely.  As explained above, even a random (simulated) process is valuable to a trader, if the random process captures the statistical features of the real process--in this case, a time series of asset prices.  But if the mathematical model is nothing more than yet another shrink-to-fit snapshot of history, it's nothing more than data mining writ large.  It's as if I generated a Fourier series that precisely matched the movement of the Dow over many years; without an underlying narrative, it's nothing but an ingenious way to draw another chart of PAST price movements. The pattern and timing of anomalies could continue to change over time in a wholly unpredictable way, in the absence of an overriding explanatory narrative.   _______________________________________  * GARCH(1,1): generalized autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity. The (1, 1) refers to the number of lags of the conditional variance and the number of lags of the squared innovations.  An example of such a study would be Thomas Lux, \\"Multi-Fractal Processes as Models for Financial Returns\\" (1999).
B002JVWR9U|5.0|I should never even have watched the first episode of the Vampire Diaries...<br /><br />I am not the target audience for either the show or the CW network (I'm 35, well past my tween, teen and college years).  Unlike many who fell in love with Dracula, Interview with a Vampire and Anne Rice, I was never into vampires or any other supernatural/science fiction melodramas.  In fact, until recently, I had never even heard of True Blood or Twilight (and I have yet to see either of those franchises).  So you may wonder -- how is it possible that I am now a Vampire Diaries addict?<br /><br />It's really very simple -- vampires or no vampires, it is the best show on television right now.<br /><br />The writing, direction, production, pacing and acting is all superb (especially given how many of the young actors on the show had little or no experience on television series before they landed this show).  The casting was spot-on (especially the three stars) and right from the beginning I was able to relate to all of the characters.  Even the guest stars have been cast perfectly (although given the death toll on this show, I have learned not to become too attached to any of the cast members, be it a guest star or one of the contract players).<br /><br />This show could easily have degenerated into an annoying teenage melodrama (especially since the first season has focused on setting up a love triangle between a seventeen year old human girl and two centuries-old vampire brothers and I have always hated triangles).  Somehow, despite its premise, the actions and reactions of the characters have managed to stay believable (for the most part) and relatable (and I don't even mind the triangle -- yet).  Even the non-supernatural storylines manage to surprise you (the teenagers don't react the way you expect TV shows to write them and the relationships are surprisingly mature, open and real).<br />Thanks to the writers, the pacing of the storylines is so fast that most story arcs begin and end within two episodes, usually by hitting you with shocking cliffhangers which are then answered immediately within the same episode or the next episode.  And, despite the dark and supernatural storylines, the show manages to not take itself too seriously and infuse just enough snarky humor to keep it entertaining.<br /><br />The show runners like to say that what drew them to the show was that it wasn't just about vampires; it was about a town with a rich history of relationships and a history of the supernatural.  That is true, but what drew me to the show were the terrific characters, writing and storylines.  Most of the time, I forget the show is even about vampires (and that is high praise, given that I'm not really a vampire lover).<br /><br />So in sum, despite my normal aversion to teenage shows, vampires and the supernatural, I am now utterly addicted to a teenage vampire drama on the CW called The Vampire Diaries -- in fact, don't bother to call or e-mail me at 8:00PM EST on Thursdays -- I won't answer because I am completely engrossed in the goings-on in a town called Mystics Falls. Come join me -- I guarantee it won't take long for you to get addicted -- maybe then, we can start a support group for TVD addicts.

B001NFNFNU|5.0|Angelina Jolie is a credit to her profession. I have seen, owned, enjoyed several of Ms. Jolie's films on DVD -- but few more so than \\"Changeling.\\" The film is, in short, a movie and a half. Director Clint Eastwood has given us a well-paced, disturbing (yet strangely uplifting), riveting picture here -- and his choice of Jolie in the lead could have been no better. She gives what one can only aptly call a truly tour-de-force performance here. The lady certainly deserved her Oscar nom for this film, and I'm sorry that \\"Changeling\\" did not make it as her 1st Best Actress win. In looking up that year's winner (2008), one can scarcely criticize Kate Winslet -- always superb as well -- so I'd not deny her what Academy voters considered a deserved win for \\"The Reader.\\" But, I must tell you: Angelina Jolie is absolutely mind-bogglingly superb in \\"Changeling.\\" Her performance is measured, often under-played (to great effect, I might add), and ultimately immensely powerful. One of the film's themes, per website Wikipedia, is female disempowerment. Well, same is a tough sell with Angie around. Her role as Christine Collins, mother to the suddenly-missing nine-year-old Walter, is anything but disempowered -- despite the all-powerful, disgustingly corrupt LAPD of 1928 and/or its fierce machinations. Why? Because Ms. Jolie, as Christine, endures it all -- and she truly is put through the mill here -- with suitable dignity, pride, strength, and a mother's fierce belief in her goal: the revelation of the truth and return of her missing son. Angelina Jolie (very properly dressed, coiffed, made-up and mannered for the period) is alternately intelligent, compelling, emotional -- while never hysterically so, unless due to completely understandable provocations -- motherly, tender and fierce. In short, she alone is perhaps the perfect match for the film's Machevalian LAPD. Several good performances here, to be sure (as well as an excellent script, despite a few unresolved holes, from which Eastwood could shoot so effectively), but \\"Changeling\\" is ultimately a one-woman show: the film belongs to Angelina Jolie; always compelling, worth watching and experiencing -- but, to date, never more so than in this marvelous, frustrating, distrurbing, yet well-worth-the-effort film.

A police officer who falls for a transient hobo (is there another kind?) who was arrested for a brutal murder?  She lets him buy her lunch and asks him to stay at her house after a few sentences of conversation across a couple of days, falling straight into bed.      Even though I didn't buy into the characters, I definitely like the author's style in writing action sequences.  These were well written and very descriptive, forming very clear images in my mind as to what was happening.    As a cheaper ebook, I'd probably try another to see if the author evolves/improves in sketching characters, but based on this first taste of this recurring character at this price, I'll probably look elsewhere for a popular fiction series to read.

Excellent songwriting by a couple of<br />  guys who know what they are doing and are totally into it renders music that is simultaneously<br />  raw & smooth, vital & immediate.  Black Keys are the king of the crop in their genre; nobody<br />  does it better!

0374531269|4.0|A Long Way Gone is a an auto biographical novel of Ishmael Beah.  It is his personal story of war in the Sierra Leone.  It all starts in 1993, when Ishmael is 12 years old.  He recounts that the war broke out in his village Mogbwemo when he was away with Junior and Talloi, learning rap music, at his grandmother's village.  Ishmael sees a Volkswagen pull up to his grandmothers house.  First, a man, vomits blood,  then a woman, and bloody children in the back.  They had tried to escape when the rebels opened fire on them.  That night, he dreams that he is shot.  He wakes up and checks the side where he dreamt he was shot, confused about what was real and what was a dream.  \\"I woke up and hesitantly touched my side, I became afraid, since I could no longer tell the difference between dream and reality.\\"(15)  Ishmael deals with the tragedies of this war in many ways.  He tries to sing rap songs, memorizing more and more lyrics in order to block out the sounds of war.  He also guides his thoughts back to his childhood, to happier days in his village, so that he can have good memories of these places that are now war torn.  He remembers a man that used to tell him to be like the moon.  His grandmother explained that the sun is sometimes to hot, and the rain is not always good, but the moon gives much happiness-therefore we should always try to be good to others, as the moon is.  \\"A lot of happy things happen when the moon shines.  These are some of the reasons why we should want to be like the moon...\\" (17)  \\"Whenever I get the chance to observe the moon now, I will see those images I saw when I was six, and it pleases me to know that that part of my childhood is still embedded in me.\\"(17)           Throughout the book, Ishmael uses stream of consciousness to go back and forth between his new life in New York City, his life during the war, and his childhood, before the war.  \\"A shudder racked my body, and I tried to think about my new life in New York City, where I had been for over a month,.  But my mind wandered across the Atlantic Ocean back to Sierra Leone.\\" (19)  \\"We opened fire until the last living being in the group fell to the ground.  We walked toward the dead bodies, giving each other high fives.  The group had also consisted of young boys like us, but we didn't care about them.  We took their ammunition, sat on their bodies, and started eating the cooked food they had been carrying.  All around us, fresh blood leaked from the bullet holes in their bodies.\\"(19)    \\"I stayed awake all night, anxiously waiting for daylight, so that I could fully return to my new life, to rediscover the happiness I had known as a child, the joy that had stayed alive inside me even through times when being alive itself became a burden.  These days I live in three worlds: my dreams, and the experiences of my new life, which trigger memories from the past.\\"(20)  He shares another painful memory of the rebels coming to their village, and the sick twisting of meaning and symbols during the war.  \\"One of the messengers was a young men.  They had carved their initials, RUF, on his body with a hot bayonet and chopped off all of his fingers with the exception of his thumbs.  The rebels called this mutilation \\"one love.\\" Before the war, people raised a thumb to say \\"One love\\" to each other, an expression popularized by the love and influence of reggae music.\\" (21)  After many years of war, Ishmael goes back to his uncle's home and meets Mr. Kamura.  Mr. Kamura works for the UN in the CAW program (Children Associated with the War).  He announces to Ishmael, that he has been chosen to go to the UN in New York City, to talk to people about the war.  This is how Ishmael comes to the United States.  He is among 57 children among 23 countries who have gathered to tell their stories at the United Nations First International Children's Parliament.  Relationships are made and Ishmael goes back to Sierra Leone with great hope.  There is peace for a time and then, another democratically chosen government is overthrown, bringing another war.  Ishmael doesn't know if he can make it this time.  \\"The entire nation crumbled into a state of lawlessness.  I hated what was happening.  I couldn't return to my previous life.  I didn't think I could make it out alive this time.\\"(203)           Though his life has been filled with tragedy, the author finds wisdom and joy in the memories of his childhood.  The author uses stream of consciousness and tribal story-telling to weave his novel and share his heart wrenching war-torn life in Sierra Leone.  His tale is a real account of modern-day war and a call for the world to wake up and work to put an end to it.  Ishmael also communicates the complexities of the war.  He ends the novel by sharing an old riddle told to the children of Siera Leone once a year.  The story goes that a hunter is hunting a monkey.  The monkey speaks: \\"If you shoot me, your mother will die, and if you don't, your father will die...\\"(217)  The children are asked, \\"What would you do if you were the hunter.\\"  Ishmael ends the novel by sharing his answer.  \\"When I was seven I had an answer to this question that made sense to me.  I never discussed it with anyone, though, for fear of how my mother would feel.  I concluded to myself that if I were the hunter, I would shoot the monkey so that it would no longer have the chance to put other hunters in the same predicament.\\"(218)
0061537969|5.0|This is such a beautifully written book.  I read this in a few days and cried and laughed throughout the book.  It is a touching story and I would definitely recommend this to any friend.

0307346617|2.0|I found out about this book by accident, when I went to Borders and asked about it (I couldn't remember the author's name) she led me right to a table where they were piled up. She said it was on summer reading lists for high school students and that made me suspicious.    The whole thing just never feels the least bit authentic; for an oral history it doesn't sound like real people talking at all. Then there are the shoehorned footnotes, my favorite was a guy explaining he was the SAW gunner, and in the same sentence said it was a light machine gun. The author felt in necessary to make a footnote describing the SAW as a light machine gun. You could have removed about a hundred and fifty pages from this thing. It's just a monotonous string of caricatures in a hodgepodge story about a zombie apocalypse.    It probably would have been better if done in the style of \\"Hiroshima\\", only because you wouldn't have the terribly awkward dialogue and back and forth between the fictional interviewer and interviewee.    It's just bad writing.

I was rooting for these two from the moment they met, and it was easy to see that this was going to carry the whole series to the very end.    This book was also extremely funny. I found myself laughing and that rarely happens to me over a book. I really enjoyed the time I spent with this series. All the books were excellent. I am so glad that this series was recommended to me, and I would recommend them to everyone else! I'm just sad it's over. 0307454541|2.0|I'm getting tired of buying books that critics have raved about, only to find that they stink.  The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is one of those books.  The pacing of this novel is incredibly slow, often getting mired in backstory and explanations, not to mention the mind-numbing repetition of the same facts: I have a memory.  I get it.<br /><br />None of the characters in this story were very interesting; they all played into some tired cliche or other, i.e. male crusader who is irresistable to women, pushy, manager type woman who has sex on her own terms, abused young woman.  I was not invested in any of their story lines, and found the plot contrivances and the characters' supposed motivations to be ridiculous.  The main character, Mikael Blomkvist is portrayed as being an honest and decent guy bent on exposing fraud.  I thought he was a self-righteous jerk.<br /><br />In addition to the horrible cliches and bad writing, I found the descriptions of sexual torture to be gratuitous and upsetting.  Other reviewers have commented that there is not a clear enough tone of condemnation in the novel for comfort, and I have to agree.  And the ending, when everyone agrees (against their better judgment) to stifle the revelation that one of the Vanger family members is a kidnapper, torturer, and rapist, I wanted to throw up.<br /><br />Overall, I have no idea why people have found this book so interesting.  Poor plot that tries to be complex, and fails, one-dimensional, unlikable characters, and shoddy writing make this a pass.

But this CD cuts it down to a little over 70 minutes, that's almost a half hour cut out. Travellin' Band which clocks in at 8:43 was edited to 5:31.  And most egregious, Rock of Ages, originally 13:49 was cut to a mere 4:53.  That's over half of their biggest hit at the time just cut out!  Additionally the 2 1/2 minute Phil Collen guitar solo after Switch 625 is just tossed away.  The odd thing is that they could have fit almost an extra 10 minutes on just the single CD, and could have fit the whole concert in if they put the first few songs on the end of the 1st CD (the studio album).  There is no excuse for this and because of this anyone who is buying this for the live concert should track down a copy of the radio broadcast instead. Its just that while I can take Reacher saving the day in an epic fashion against a hoard of bad guys, I cant see some nomadic dude wandering across the country ending up in fights equal to James Bond scenarios.<br /><br />Reacher is obviously 100% crafted on the character of Rambo. In Bad Luck and Trouble, he is Rambo with a mathematical mind worthy of Matt Damon in Good Will Hunting. He buys a new shirt twice in this story and changes out of his old one in the store, throwing the old one away. He says that he doesn't like to get bogged down with baggage. Hmmmm, didn't change his underwear for the entire novel? Must have been getting pretty ripe.<br /><br />I really dont like series' that turn the main character into superheros from one book to the next. Here Reacher is not quite a superhero, but he has the ability to be walking down a very busy street talking with his friends and is able to react to the sound of a muffled round being chambered 20-30 feet behind him.<br /><br />Silly timing starts off the book. One of his old army buddies puts 1030 dollars into his account at a bank. All seven of Reachers friends talk in worshipful observance of the Special Investigators to their friends and families. Why is it that in this, the 11th Reacher book we hear about them for the first time? B003FMTZOM|5.0|Wow. Christina you're really reaching out and opening up with this whole album. What an eclectic mix of heart-felt songs and blatant dance tracks. Sexy and irreverent, yet remaining literally tongue-in-cheek throughout. I give it a five star rating out of five. Of course, I love everything you do. Here's my first reaction to the CD my step-mother (the Chief Flight Attendant) just brought me back from China!    1. Bionic    Bionic, with its staggered beat and reverse-echoed, hole-punched vocals, is one of my favorite tracks on the album. It could be that this is because it's the lead track on the album which has been playing over and over, most of the day and night. The vocal phrasing on this song is immaculate. The \\"Ready to Go\\" part reminds me of that song by Republica. Was that on purpose? X=X-X-T-T-T-I-I-I-N-N-N-A-A-A!    2. Not Myself Tonight     \\"Wanna get crazy?\\" you ask at the outset. X-Tina's breaking out and \\"kissing all the boys and the girls\\" with this one, and you're \\"in rare form\\" from beginning to end. It's definitely sexy enough to turn the boys to men and the men (like me) to boys. Girls are always going to have a love-hate thing with you, Ms. Aguilera, hating the brashness on the surface but secretly wishing they were you when it comes to crafting and delivering a purr-fect song. The last verse sounds like a classic Donna Summer vocal until the robo-hole-punched thing happens again. Thought my player was messing up the first time I heard that, but I think I do like it.    3. Woohoo feat. Nicki Minaj     This one is classic. It defies critique. Hats off to Nicki for the backups and interior rap. The \\"you know you wanna put your lips where my hips are\\" line made me start the track over several times. My eleven year-old son looked at me funny and I had to say \\"Yep, that's what she said\\". This track is best enjoyed with a good set of head-phones in a dimly lit room with a couple of bong rips. The rastafari part at the end makes me wanna scream...\\"Woohoo!!\\"    4. Elastic Love     More electronic pulsations to start the track, and I feel a bit of a Devo influence... maybe a nod to the ladies of the eighties, like Karla DeVito, Whale or Missing Persons. I dunno. It's not noticeably derivative, just seems \\"New Wave\\" in a nostalgic way if that's possible. Oingo Boingo meets Elastica with a twist. Makes me want to hear the Aquilera version of \\"I know What Boys Like\\" by the Waitresses.      5. Desnudate     This one makes me think Lady Gaga has been spinning in the Aguilera iPod a bit. Of course, when Gaga hit the scene, I thought her impersonation of you was pretty good. Her early works weren't that great, and I know she has the Aguilera influence to thank for a few of her vocal stylings. A little droning, but the \\"Get Naked... for Me\\" backup chants and exasperated moans in the chorus and at the end are a highlight. The only thing I don't like throughout the album are the \\"hand-clap\\" drumbeats. They remind me of sitcom laugh-tracks for some reason, like we're supposed to clap along or something. Just a pet peeve, and not that noticable unless you have programmed yourself to notice it, like me.    6. Love & Glamour (intro)     This part is a little self-indulgent, but we loves it when you do that, we do!    7. Glam     THis one substitutes a finger-snap for the claps. Maybe it's because I just watched you, and then Janet Jackson, perform on the American Idol finale', but this isn't one of my favorite songs on the album. I still like it 'cause it's you, but it reminds me of that whispery style that Janet uses all the time now... right up to the middle part where the Aguilera wails come in. That's the amazing part that saves the song. Still, a filler track for you would be a #1 single for Ms. Jackson... 'cept she couldn't pull off the wailing part to save her life!    8. Prima Donna     The farther I go with this album the more I understand the cover art. Amazing vocals with synthesized claps for a snare beat... confusingly electronic but still naughtily nice. \\"I'm a Prima Donna. I can rule the World!\\" indeed!! The bass drum on this one has my speakers jumping around the room. The synth keyboards are mixed so low that the vocal seems almost a capela with drums. The percussion track adds a nice effect at spots and the weird chorus on the backing vocals is surreal.    9. Morning Dessert (intro)     This is some really sexy stuff, pretty lady. \\"Touch me here, touch me there...let me give you Morning Dessert.\\" I hope your guy appreciates this stuff, 'cause the rest of us are getting very jealous.    10. Sex For Breakfast     Excuse me. I'll be back for the next song. I can't write while this one is on. The lyrics are so sweetly cruel. To really experience the vibe of this song, the listener should get some Strawbery Cream and the One you Love handy before starting the track.    11. Lift Me Up     Now, where was I... Oh yeah, the review. Lift Me Up is a hit single for sure! Might have been the best choice for the 1st one out of the gate. A more traditional song than \\"Not Myself Tonight\\" all the way around. The drums sounds are real and not over-played, the bass is very well mixed and though there is still some spacey ambient noodling going on, the vocals are just plain perfect. This is why I started listening to you in the first place. \\"Rise Above\\" Milady, you don't need a boost!! I might have to put this one up on my Blog (just kidding).    12. My Heart (Intro)     Nice touch on the \\"Ma Ma\\" part, Max.    13. All I Need     Please don't ever let anyone cover this song or use it in a commercial. It's so personal, and we do appreciate the window into your \\"real world\\" and the precious relationship you share with your son. As a parent of three, I can identify with the full sentiment of this song. My 24 year-old daughter, Tiger Natasha, introduced me to your music and nearly drove me crazy with \\"Genie\\" back in the day. I called your publicist and arranged a phone interview for her \\"Glitz Teen-Zine\\" website back then and she freaked out. Now, all these years later I'm sure you are a wonderful mother, and now it is I who have become a great fan of your music.    14. I Am     This album is like a trip to Disney World. The electronic pulse is fading and giving way to a very sentimental and traditional sounding core. I love this song. It's a mellow piano ballad, but just as powerful as anything I've heard so far. Reminds me of the better Fiona Apple songs like \\"Extraordinary Machine\\" or \\"Never Is A Promise\\".    15. You Lost Me     The old \\"one-two punch\\", eh? A great piano ballad followed by the jewel of the album. Another single, and I hope this one has a video interpretation, too. I just saw you it \\"live\\" on American Idol! I'd like to see it in person, that is If the tour does eventually happen and I can manage to get a refund for the tickets I bought for the cancelled Summer show in S.F. You should close the show with this song as an encore. Amazing.    16. I Hate Boys     This one reminds me of the \\"Beautifulgarbage\\" era tracks by Shirley Manson and Garbage. Of course, you have a lot more range than Shirl, and they use heavy guitars... but believe me, it's a compliment.    17. My Girls feat. Peaches     It's great how you smoothly morphed back into the cover android at the end of the album. Synth sounds abound, and a cool Elastica-like bass riff, too. Peaches reaches with the \\"BFF\\" bit. Best to leave that stuff for the next Paris Hilton album. It's a Gurl-Power anthem, sort of... but not the best track on your album. It's more like a Pink or Gwen Stefani song, and in high-contrast to the previous three on the CD.    18. Vanity     Are you Snow White or the Wicked Queen? This song would seem to imply the latter. \\"I make myself so much wetter\\" and \\"I turn myself on!\\" are a couple of highlights. My sister talks to the mirror, too, but that's a different story and she takes meds for that. I'm not sure I would have ended the album with this track, but it's agood one for the X-Tina \\"alter\\" files. I think you should perform this one with the Pussycat Dolls or Spice Girls or something for full effect.    All in all, I love this album and will buy copies for all of my friends.  XXXOOOXXX

B003JTHXN6|4.0|\\"A customer is the most important visitor on our premises.<br />He is not dependent on us. We are dependent on him.<br />He is not an interruption in our work - he is the purpose of it.<br />We are not doing him a favour by serving him. He is doing us a favour by giving us the opportunity to serve him.\\" - M.K. Gandhi<br /><br />Delivering Happiness is about Pleasure, Passion and Purpose. Tony Hsieh is an instant inspiration to anyone who wants to start a company and(or) formulate a set of core values that the employees actually follow. As they say, actions speak louder than words. That's exactly what Tony is about. A man of actions. A no nonsense CEO. A no BS leader.<br /><br />What started as a quest for earning money quickly turned into something purposeful. You can feel the transition of Pleasure into Passion and ultimately to Purpose. The Purpose that keeps him, his employees and his customers happy. His thirst for achieving something big is clearly evident in every word of this book. I am sure He will not stop with Zappos! He is meant for something big, something of greater value and purpose.<br /><br />This book is not a biography but gives you a fair picture of Tony's personality as an achiever and a passionate leader, someone who always wants to break the rules and go against conventions to achieve his purpose. A living example of someone who works relentlessly towards his goals. I, for one, drew a lot of inspiration.<br /><br />A company is a living being and it is the responsibility of the leadership to give it a face, a character, a culture, values and principles. Also, employees must be able to connect themselves to the values and principles. Most companies come up with \\"Core Values\\" that employees hardly remember. This book gives you clear understanding of why those values are important and why it is more important for employees to follow them and why companies fail if it fails to inspire it's employees.<br /><br />Tony writes all about this in this fun filled roller coaster ride of successes and disappointments. This is a book of inspiration, motivation, advice. This a book about what makes us happy. This not only applies to running a business, but also to an individual looking for higher levels of happiness in life. This is a fairy tale of hard work, achievement, success, uncertainty and of course, profits. A must read for budding entrepreneurs and leaders who want to build some culture.intments. This not only applies to running a business, but also to an individual looking for higher levels of happiness in life. This is a fairy tale of hard work, achievement, success, uncertainty and of course, profits. A must read for budding entrepreneurs and leaders who want to build some culture.
1931559317|4.0|I used to use planisphere for a while for finding stars and other sky objects but I thought I could use more detailed information for night sky.    This sky atlas seems to be reasonably well organized for finding or locating DSO(deep sky objects).  With spiral handy book, it's easy to keep same page open for a while compare to other types of paperback which require some other entity to keep the same page.  It's been organized for spring, summer , fall, and winder along with good time zone for observing certain DSOs.  The one thing I find bothering is that on the alphabetical search page, the constellation names and matching page numbers  are printed rather too small to read easily, especially at night with just red dim light.  They could have used larger bold face letters or so for readers to read easily.    However, overall it's not too bad with many DSOs in the constellation with reasonable accuracy for the price.  It's sturdy pocket book for more detailed information compare to most planispheres.    Isaac
B0000AYLLQ|3.0|Not bad, but not the best french language album from Celine.  If you're an english speaking fan, you should skip this album and just buy the On Ne Change Pas which features hits from this album.  The vocals on this album and in general her french albums are just as or sometimes more melodic than her english albums but the vocal strength of the performances are not as dynamic or powerful...but still good enough to buy the french albums for cheap.
B000002AH7|3.0|I am an admirer of both Miles Davis and Rodrigo's Concierto de Aranjuez but I found the combination disappointing. I thought that Davis even sounded flat on occasion. Pity, so I think I'll stick to the guitar version for this piece of music in future and enjoy Miles playing the ballads.
0375842209|5.0|I'm not going to get into the content or plot of this book.I'm going to give my impression of this book.    It's narrated by a sardonic death tired of humanity's unquestionable need to kill one another.From the opening scene to the ending Death literal and figuratively haunt's this novel.It's a dark and bitter reflection on humanity.It's also a story of how we manage to find a small piece of comfort and sanity in a world blown to hell.If you have any interest in war time Germany or the dark side of humanity and how we manage to survive this book is for you.This is one of those books that will haunt me for years to come and is one of the most heart-wrenching book's I've read.    One side note I have no idea why this book was marketed to kids,it's is way to dark for most kids.
1935251740|3.0|Lanza and Berman bring up some interesting points - namely it is humans that superimpose all of the notions of science, religion, etc. on a universe that doesn't exist unless we exist in it. The idea of light being the fastest anything can travel is disspelled, is one of the many notions that science is trying to wrestle with. Biocentrism says it is because of us that we don't understand it and when we think we do, another notion comes to challenge it. The limitations of homo sapien sapiens is also the limitations of science. The key concepts of science and our misunderstandings of them are well-presented in this book. The biggest bump in reading this, was how Lanza interjected his personel trials into the book. Overall, an unusal concept in science that needs more exploration and better work.
